{{Multiple issues| {{BLP sources|date=December 2017}} {{Cleanup rewrite|date=December 2017}}}} {{Infobox writer <!-- for more information see [[:Template:Infobox writer/doc]] --> |name = K Y Narayanaswamy |image = File:K_Y_Narayanaswamy.jpg |birth_date = {{birth date and age|mf=yes|1965|06|05}} |birth_place = Kuppur village near Masthi, Malur taluk, [[Kolar district]], [[Karnataka]] |occupation = Kannada Language Professor, Playwright & Poet |nationality = [[India]]n |alma_mater = [[Bangalore University]] |awards = [[Karnataka Sahitya Academy Award]] | nickname = KYN }}
'''Kuppur Yalappa Narayanaswamy''', also known as '''KYN''', is a popular Kannada poet, scholar, critic, and playwright. He is currently a Kannada professor in the Government Arts College, Bangalore. He is the author of many popular Kannada plays including ''Kalavu, Anabhigna Shakuntala, Chakraratna, Huliseere,'' and ''Vinura Vema''. He has also translated Kuvempu’s ''Shudra Tapaswi'' into Telugu. He is credited with adapting Kuvempu’s magnum opus ''[[Malegalalli madumagalu]]'' into a 9-hour play. He has also written the screenplay for the films ''Kalavu''<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2913910/|title=Kalavu|website=IMDb.com|accessdate=4 December 2017}}</ref> and ''[[Suryakaanti]]''.
He won the Karnataka Sahitya Akademi Award<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.karnatakasahithyaacademy.org/downloads/Book_Prize2005.pdf|format=PDF|title=2005£ÉAiÀÄ ¸Á°£À §ºÀÄªÀiÁ¤vÀ ¥ÀÄ¸ÀÛPÀUÀ¼ÀÄ|website=Karnatakasahityaacademy.org|accessdate=4 December 2017}}</ref> for his play ''Pampabharatha'', which is considered a milestone in modern Kannada theatre. He is considered to be an influential writer and thinker. His plays are representative of Kannada theatre’s search for new frontiers in experimental theatre.
==Biography== KYN was born in Kuppur village near Masthi in Malur Taluk, Kolar district, Karnataka. He was born to Yalappa and Muniyamma. He finished his schooling in Masthi and moved to Bangalore to obtain his BA, MA and M.Phil degrees in Kannada. His PhD, titled ''Neeradeevige'', is considered a milestone in the societal understanding of cultural associations with water. He currently lives in Bangalore with his wife and two children.
==Writing career== KYN first came into prominence with his play ''Pampabharatha'', whose essence is based on Adikavi Pampa’s epic poem ''Vikramarjunavijaya'', which is also known as ''Pampabharatha''. While Pampa’s epic relates the Mahabharatha from the perspective of Arjuna, KYN’s play is based on Karna’s viewpoint of events in Mahabharatha. However, the play is also a deconstruction of Pampa’s version and the Mahabharatha itself, and it moves the narration to contemporary times and also focuses on issues of contemporary relevance. The play, staged by the theatre group Samudaya, has seen a hundred shows.
Since Pampabharatha, his other plays such as ''Kalavu, Anabhigna Shakuntala'', and ''Male Mantrika'' have been widely appreciated by Kannada audiences. He is currently working on a new play tentatively titled ''Mallige''.
In 2010, KYN adapted Kuvempu’s ''Malegalalli Madumagalu'' ''(The Bride in the Mountains)'' into a 9-hour play<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20130909235156/http://caravanmagazine.in/lede/dusk-dawn] </ref> that was directed by noted theatre director and NSD alumnus [[C. Basavalingaiah]]. The play was staged about 15 times each in Bangalore and Mysore, and showcased to nearly 60,000 audience members.
KYN also co-authored the script for the light and sound show ''Manushya Jathi Tanonde Valam''<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20141015151935/http://karnatakavarthe.org/en/manushya-jati-tanonde-valam-2/] </ref> with Kotaganahalli Ramaiah and Lakshmipathy Kolar. This show, also directed by Basavalingaiah, with music composed by famed music director Hamsalekha, was staged in 28 districts in Karnataka.
KYN has also written screenplays for the films ''Kalavu'' (a cinematic adaptation of his play) and ''Suryakaanti''. He is currently working on screenplays with renowned Kannada film directors TS Nagabharana and Nagathihalli Chandrashekar.
He has curated a music album titled ''Kolar Desi Gold'',<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newindianexpress.com/cities/bangalore/article1239933.ece|title=Keeping the folk tradition alive|website=Newindianexpress.com|accessdate=4 December 2017}}</ref> with music scored by Hamsalekha. The album is a compilation of Telugu folk songs that have also been translated into Kannada. He has written the lyrics for the music album ''Kailamp'' ''(KYN love songs)'',<ref>{{cite web|url=http://newindianexpress.com/cities/bangalore/Trio-release-music-album-for-mentor/2013/11/23/article1906622.ece|title=Trio release music album for mentor|website=Newindianexpress.com|accessdate=4 December 2017}}</ref> with music being composed by his student Arvinda SD and the songs sung by an ensemble of popular singers in styles ranging from classical and folk to jazz.
As a Kannada professor, KYN has authored the Kannada text Sahitya Samvada -1 for Bangalore University.
==Plays== *Pampabharatha *Kalavu *Huliseere *Male Mantrika (an adaptation of the play The Rainmaker by Richard Nash) *Anabhigna Shakuntala *Chakrarathna *Malegalalli Madumagalu<ref>{{cite web |url=http://madhumagaluplay.in/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2016-02-15 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160220015433/http://madhumagaluplay.in/ |archivedate=2016-02-20 |df= }}</ref> (based on the book by Kuvempu) *Manushya Jathi Tanonde Valam (light and sound show, co-author with Kotaganahalli Ramaiah and Lakshmipathy Kolar) *Vinura Vema *Shudra Tapaswi (translation of Kuvempu’s play into Telugu) *Kaivara Nareyana
==Films== *Adikavi Pampa (Documentary, Scriptwriter) *Suryakaanti (Screenplay) *Kalavu (Story & Screenplay)
==Music== *Kolar Desi Gold (curated) *Kailamp (KYN love songs)
==Books== *Aduva Giliyonda Kalisamma, Poetry, Published by Christ College, Bengaluru-2000. *Neera Deevige, Research Thesis, Published by Lohiya Prakashana, Ballary- 2000 and 2nd Edition Published by Pragathi Graphics, Bengaluru-2007. *Thalaparige, Co-editor, Published by Dr.B.R.Ambedkar Development Corporation, Govt. of Karnataka, Bengaluru-2006. *Bharamma Bhagirathi mathu ithara lekanagalu, Street Plays, Published by Sirivara Prakashana, Bengaluru-2006. *Bahubali, a children’s play, 2nd Edition Published by Rangayana, Mysore- 2006. *Nenava Pari, a collection of criticism articles, Published by Pragathi Graphics, Bengaluru-2010.
==Awards== *Karnataka Sahitya Akademi Award for Pampabharatha(2005) and Anabhigna Shakuntala(2013) *Karnataka International Music Award 2013 and 2014 (for Anabhigna Shakuntala and Male Mantrika) *State Award 2014 for best screenplay (Kalavu) *Karnataka Sahitya Akademi Award for `Nenevapari' (Published Year 2010)
==Other activities== KYN is a founding member of the Besagarahalli Ramannna Trust, which provides scholarships and financial aid to needy students. The Trust also organizes annual rural summer camps.
Together with other lecturers of Government Science College, KYN started a midday meal scheme for students.
KYN has initiated a program titled Kuvempu Odu (Read Kuvempu) along with [[K V Narayana]]. The program identifies various colleges across Karnataka and introduces students to Kuvempu’s writings and philosophy.
==See also== {{portal|Poetry}} * [[Kannada language|Kannada]] * [[Kannada literature]] * [[Kannada poetry]]
==References== {{Reflist}}

revision.text:
{{multiple image | align = | direction = vertical | background color = <!-- box background --> | width = 340 | caption_align = <!-- left (default), center, right -->
| header_background = | header_align = <!-- center (default), left, right --> | header =
| image1 = Foire saint-germain.jpg | width1 = <!-- displayed width of image; overridden by "width" above --> | caption1 = The Paris foire St Germain, c. 1763, after the fire of 1762
| image2 = Foire saint-laurent.jpg | width2 = <!-- displayed width of image; overridden by "width" above --> | alt2 = | caption2 = Nicolet's theatre at the foire St Laurent, c. 1786
| footer_background = | footer_align = left | footer = In the early 18th century, the [[Théâtre de la foire]] in [[Paris]] – a collective name for the theatres at the annual fairs at St Germain, St Laurent (see illustration above) and later, St Ovide – offered performances with both music and spoken dialogue. First called [[comédie en vaudeville]], these developed into the [[opéra comique]]. The Théâtre de la foire appeared in [[London]] in the 1720s, to be imitated in the form of the English [[ballad opera]], which in turn stimulated the creation of the German [[Singspiel]]. }} This is an inclusive [[glossary]] '''list of opera genres''', giving alternative names.
"Opera" is an Italian word (short for "opera in musica"), however it was not ''commonly'' used in Italy (or indeed in other countries) to refer to the genre of particular works. Most composers used more precise designations to present their work to the public. Often specific genres of opera were commissioned by theatres or patrons (in which case the form of the work might deviate more or less from the genre norm, depending on the inclination of the composer). Opera genres are not exclusive. Some operas are regarded as belonging to several.<ref>For example, ''[[Don Giovanni]]'' is regularly referred to as both a [[dramma giocoso]] and an [[opera buffa]], however [[Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart|Mozart]] himself called the work an [[opera buffa]].</ref>
==Definitions== Opera genres have been defined in different ways, not always in terms of stylistic rules. Some, like [[opera seria]], refer to traditions identified by later historians,<ref name=OS>McClymonds, Marita P and [[Daniel Heartz|Heartz, Daniel]]: "Opera seria" in ''[[The New Grove Dictionary of Opera]]'', ed. [[Stanley Sadie]] (London, 1992) {{ISBN|0-333-73432-7}}</ref> while others, like [[Zeitoper]], have been defined by their own inventors. Other forms have been associated with a particular theatre, for example [[opéra comique]] at the [[Opéra-Comique|theatre of the same name]], or [[opéra bouffe]] at the [[Théâtre des Bouffes Parisiens]].
This list does not include terms that are vague and merely descriptive, such as '[[comic opera]]',<ref>"A general name for an operatic work in which the prevailing mood is one of comedy." [[John Warrack|Warrack John]]; Ewan West, ''The Oxford Dictionary of Opera'', (1992), {{ISBN|0-19-869164-5}}</ref> 'sacred opera', 'tragic opera' or 'one-act opera' etc. Original language terms are given to avoid the ambiguities that would be caused by English translations.{{clear}}
==List== {| class="wikitable sortable" !|Genre!!Language!!class="unsortable" width="36%"|Description!!|First known example!!class="unsortable"|Major works!!|Last known example!!class="unsortable"|Notable composers!!class="unsortable"|Refs. |- | {{Anchor|Acte de ballet}}Acte de ballet || [[French language|French]] || An [[opéra ballet]] consisting of a single entrée. 18th century. || || ''[[Les fêtes de Ramire]]'' (1745), ''[[Anacréon (1754)|Anacréon]]'' (1754), || || [[Jean-Philippe Rameau|Rameau]] || <ref name=OD>[[John Warrack|Warrack, John]] and West, Ewan (1992), ''The Oxford Dictionary of Opera'', 782 pages, {{ISBN|0-19-869164-5}}</ref> |- | [[Afterpiece]] || [[English language|English]] || 18th/early 19th century short opera or pantomime performed after a full-length play. || || ''[[The Padlock]]'' (1768)|| || [[Charles Dibdin|Dibdin]] || <ref name=OD /> |- | {{Anchor|Azione sacra}}Azione sacra || [[Italian language|Italian]] ||''Literally'', 'sacred action'. 17th and early 18th century opera with religious subject. Performed at [[Vienna]] court. || || ''L'humanità redenta'' ([[Antonio Draghi|Draghi]], 1669) || || [[Antonio Draghi|Draghi]], [[Antonio Bertali|Bertali]], Pietro Andrea Ziani, Giovanni Battista Pederzuoli, [[Antonio Cesti|Cesti]] || <ref name=OD /> |- | {{Anchor|Azione sepolcrale}}Azione sepolcrale || Italian ||''alternative name for'' azione sacra || || || || || <ref name=OD /> |- | {{Anchor|Azione scenica}}Azione scenica || Italian ||''alternative name for'' azione teatrale || || ||{{Hs|1975}}''[[Al gran sole carico d'amore]]'' (1975)|| || <ref name=OD /> |- | [[Azione teatrale]] (plural ''azioni teatrali'')|| Italian || Small-scale one-act opera, or musical play. Early form of chamber opera. Popular in late 17th and 18th centuries. (See also ''[[festa teatrale]]'', a similar genre but on a larger scale.) || || ''[[Le cinesi]]'' (1754), ''[[Il sogno di Scipione]]'' (1772), ''[[L'isola disabitata]]'' (1779) || || [[Giuseppe Bonno|Bonno]], [[Christoph Willibald Gluck|Gluck]], [[Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart|Mozart]], [[Joseph Haydn|Haydn]]|| <ref name=OD /> |- | [[Ballad opera]] || English ||Entertainment originating in 18th-century [[London]] as a reaction against Italian opera. Early examples used existing popular ballad tunes set to satirical texts. Also popular in [[Dublin]] and America, Influenced the German [[Singspiel]], and subsequently 20th-century opera. ||{{Hs|1728}}''[[The Beggar's Opera]]'' (1728) || ''[[Love in a Village]]'' (1762), ''[[Hugh the Drover]]'' (1924), ''[[The Threepenny Opera]]'' (1928) || || [[Johann Christoph Pepusch|Pepusch]], [[Charles Coffey|Coffey]], [[Thomas Arne|Arne]], [[Kurt Weill|Weill]] || <ref name=OD /> |- | {{Anchor|Ballet héroïque}}Ballet héroïque || French || ''Literally'' 'heroic ballet'. A type of [[opéra ballet]] featuring the heroic and exotic, of the early/mid 18th century.||{{Hs|1723}}''Les festes grecques et romaines'' ([[François Colin de Blamont|Colin de Blamont]], 1723)|| ''[[Zaïde, reine de Grenade]]'' (1739), ''[[Les fêtes de Paphos]]'' (1758) || || [[Joseph-Nicolas-Pancrace Royer|Royer]], [[Jean-Joseph de Mondonville|Mondonville]], [[Charles-Louis Mion|Mion]] || <ref name=OD /> |- | {{Anchor|Bühnenfestspiel}}Bühnenfestspiel || [[German language|German]] || ''Literally'', 'stage festival play'. [[Richard Wagner|Wagner]]'s description of the four operas of ''[[Der Ring des Nibelungen]]'' || || || || [[Richard Wagner|Wagner]] || <ref name=OD /> |- | {{Anchor|Bühnenweihfestspiel}}Bühnenweihfestspiel || German || ''Literally'', 'stage consecration festival play'. [[Richard Wagner|Wagner]]'s description for ''[[Parsifal]]'' || || || || [[Richard Wagner|Wagner]] || <ref name=OD /> |- | {{Anchor|Burla}}Burla || Italian || ''alternative name for'' [[burletta]] || || || || || <ref name=OD /> |- | [[Burletta]] || Italian || ''Literally'', 'little joke'. Informal term for comic pieces in the 18th century. Used in England for [[Intermezzo#Opera intermezzo|intermezzos]] and light, satirical works.|| || ''[[The Recruiting Serjeant]]'' (1770) || || [[Charles Dibdin|Dibdin]] || <ref name=OD /> |- | {{Anchor|Burletta per musica}}Burletta per musica || Italian || ''alternative name for'' [[burletta]] || || ''Il vero originale'' ([[Simon Mayr|Mayr]] 1808)|| || || |- | {{Anchor|Burlettina}}Burlettina || Italian || ''alternative name for'' [[burletta]] || |||| || || <ref name=OD /> |- | {{Anchor|Characterposse}}Characterposse || German || Specialized form of [[Posse mit Gesang]] concentrating on personalities. || || || || || <ref name=OD /> |- | [[Comédie en vaudeville]] || French || Entertainment in [[Théâtre de la foire|Paris fair theatres]] at the end of the 17th century, mixing popular [[vaudeville (song)|vaudeville]] songs with comedy. In the 18th century, developed into the [[opéra comique]], while influencing directly the English [[ballad opera]] and indirectly the German [[Singspiel]].|| || || || || |- | {{Anchor|Comédie lyrique}}Comédie lyrique || French || ''Literally'', 'lyric comedy'. 18th century: description used by [[Jean-Philippe Rameau|Rameau]]. 19th century: alternative name for opéra lyrique. || || ''[[Platée]]'' (1745), ''[[Les Paladins]]'' (1760) || || [[Jean-Philippe Rameau|Rameau]] || <ref>Sadler, Graham: ''Rameau, Jean-Philippe'' in ''[[The New Grove Dictionary of Opera]]'', ed. Stanley Sadie (London, 1992) {{ISBN|0-333-73432-7}}</ref> |- | [[Comédie mêlée d'ariettes]] ||French || ''Literally'', 'comedy mixed with brief arias'. An early form of [[France|French]] [[opéra comique]] dating to the mid 18th century.|| || ''[[La rencontre imprévue]]'' (1764), ''[[Tom Jones (Philidor)|Tom Jones]]'' (1765), ''[[Le déserteur]]'' (1769), ''[[Zémire et Azor]]'' (1771), ''Le congrès des rois'' ([[Luigi Cherubini|Cherubini]] ''et al.'', 1794) || || [[Christoph Willibald Gluck|Gluck]], [[André Grétry|Grétry]] || |- | {{Anchor|Commedia}}Commedia || Italian ||''abbreviation of'' commedia in musica || || ''[[Il barbiere di Siviglia]]'' (1816) || || || |- | {{Anchor|Commedia in musica}}Commedia in musica || Italian ||''alternative name for'' [[opera buffa]] || || || || || <ref name=PW>Weiss, Piero and [[Julian Budden|Budden, Julian]] (1992): "Opera buffa" in ''[[The New Grove Dictionary of Opera]]'', ed. [[Stanley Sadie]] (London) {{ISBN|0-333-73432-7}}</ref> |- | {{Anchor|Commedia per musica}}Commedia per musica || Italian || ''alternative name for'' [[opera buffa]] || || ''[[La pastorella nobile]]'' (1788)|| || || <ref name=PW /> |- | {{Anchor|Componimento da camera}}Componimento da camera || Italian || ''alternative name for'' azione teatrale || || || || || <ref name=OD /> |- | {{Anchor|Componimento drammatico}}Componimento drammatico || Italian || ''alternative name for'' azione teatrale || || || || || <ref name=OD /> |- | {{Anchor|Componimento pastorale}}Componimento pastorale || Italian || ''alternative name for'' azione teatrale || || ''La danza'' (Gluck, 1755) || || [[Christoph Willibald Gluck|Gluck]]|| <ref name=OD /> |- | {{Anchor|Conte lyrique}}Conte lyrique || French ||''alternative name for'' opéra lyrique || || ''[[Grisélidis]]'' (Massenet, 1901) || || || <ref name=OD /> |- | {{Anchor|Divertimento giocoso}}Divertimento giocoso || Italian || ''alternative name for'' [[opera buffa]] || || || || || <ref name=PW /> |- | {{Anchor|Dramatic opera}}{{Anchor|Dramatick opera}}Dramatic (or dramatick) opera || English || ''alternative name for'' [[semi-opera]] || || || || || |- | {{Anchor|Drame forain}}Drame forain || French || ''alternative name for'' [[Comédie en vaudeville]] || || || || || <ref name=OD /> |- | {{Anchor|Drame lyrique}}Drame lyrique || French || ''Literally'', 'lyric drama'. (1) Term used in the 18th century. (2) Reinvented in the late 19th/early 20th century to describe opera that developed out of [[opéra comique]], influenced by [[Jules Massenet|Massenet]]. || || ''[[Echo et Narcisse]]'' (1779), ''[[La marquise de Brinvilliers (opera)|La marquise de Brinvilliers]]'' (1831), ''[[Werther]] (1892), ''[[Briséïs]]'' (1897), ''[[Messidor (opera)|Messidor]]'' (1897) || || [[Christoph Willibald Gluck|Gluck]], [[Emmanuel Chabrier|Chabrier]], [[Alfred Bruneau|Bruneau]], [[Camille Erlanger|Erlanger]] || <ref name=OD /> |- | {{Anchor|Dramma bernesco}}Dramma bernesco || Italian || ''alternative name for'' [[opera buffa]] || || || || || <ref name=PW /> |- | {{Anchor|Dramma comico}}Dramma comico || Italian || ''alternative name for'' [[opera buffa]], 18th/early 19th century. Also used for the genre that replaced it from mid 19th century, with the elimination of [[recitative]]s. || || || || || <ref name=PW /> |- | {{Anchor|Dramma comico per musica}}Dramma comico per musica || Italian || ''alternative name for'' dramma comico || || || || || |- | {{Anchor|Dramma di sentimento}}Dramma di sentimento || Italian || ''alternative name for'' [[opera semiseria]] || || || || || <ref name=OD /> |- | {{Anchor|Dramma eroicomico}}Dramma eroicomico || Italian || ''Literally'' 'heroic-comic drama'. A late 18th century [[opera buffa]] with some heroic content. || || ''[[Orlando paladino]]'' (1782), ''[[Palmira, regina di Persia]]'' (1795)|| || [[Joseph Haydn|Haydn]], [[Antonio Salieri|Salieri]] || <ref name=OD /> |- | [[Dramma giocoso]] (plural ''drammi giocosi'')|| Italian ||''Literally'', 'jocular drama'. Mid 18th century form that developed out of the [[opera buffa]], marked by the addition of serious, even tragic roles and situations to the comic ones. (Effectively a subgenre of [[opera buffa]] in the 18th century.) <ref>[[Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart|Mozart]]'s [[Don Giovanni]], a typical [[dramma giocoso]], was called an [[opera buffa]].</ref> || || ''[[La scuola de' gelosi]]'' (1778), ''[[La vera costanza]]'' (1779), ''[[Il viaggio a Reims]]'' (1825), || || [[Joseph Haydn|Haydn]], [[Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart|Mozart]], [[Antonio Salieri|Salieri]], [[Giuseppe Sarti|Sarti]], [[Gioachino Rossini|Rossini]], [[Gaetano Donizetti|Donizetti]] || <ref name=OD /> |- | {{Anchor|Dramma giocoso per musica}}Dramma giocoso per musica || Italian || ''full term for'' [[dramma giocoso]] || || || || || |- | {{Anchor|Dramma pastorale}}Dramma pastorale || Italian ||''Literally'', 'pastoral drama'. Used for some of the earliest operas down to the 18th century. || || ''Eumelio'' ([[Agostino Agazzari|Agazzari]], 1606), ''La fede riconosciuta'' ([[Alessandro Scarlatti|A Scarlatti]], 1710) || || [[Alessandro Scarlatti|A Scarlatti]], [[Giuseppe Sarti|Sarti]] || <ref name=OD /> |- |[[Dramma per musica]] (plural ''drammi per musica'') || Italian || ''Literally'', 'drama for music', or 'a play intended to be set to music' (i.e. a [[libretto]]). Later, synonymous with [[opera seria]]; in the 19th century, sometimes used for serious opera. || ||''[[Erismena]]'' (1656), ''[[Tito Manlio]]'' (1719), ''[[Paride ed Elena]]'' (1770), ''[[Idomeneo]]'' (1781), [[Rossini]]'s ''[[Otello (Rossini)|Otello]]'' (1816) || ||[[Alessandro Scarlatti|A Scarlatti]], [[Francesco Cavalli|Cavalli]], [[Antonio Vivaldi|Vivaldi]], [[Giuseppe Sarti|Sarti]], [[Christoph Willibald Gluck|Gluck]], [[Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart|Mozart]] || <ref name=OD /> |- | {{Anchor|Dramma semiserio}}Dramma semiserio || Italian || ''alternative name for'' [[opera semiseria]] || || ''[[Torvaldo e Dorliska]]'' (1815)|| || || |- | {{Anchor|Dramma tragicomico}}Dramma tragicomico || Italian || ''alternative name for'' [[opera semiseria]]. || || ''[[Axur, re d'Ormus]]'' (1787)|| || || <ref name=OD /> |- | [[Entr'acte]] || French || French name for [[Intermezzo#Opera intermezzo|intermezzo]] || || || || || <ref name=OD /> |- | {{Anchor|Episode lyrique}}Episode lyrique || French ||''alternative name for'' opéra lyrique || || || || || <ref name=OD /> |- | {{Anchor|Fait historique}}Fait historique || French ||Late 18th/19th century. Opéra or opéra comique based on French history, especially popular during the [[French revolution|revolution]]. || ''L'incendie du Havre'' (1786)|| ''Joseph Barra'' ([[André Grétry|Grétry]] 1794), ''Le pont de Lody'' ([[Étienne Méhul|Méhul]] 1797), ''[[Milton (opera)|Milton]]'' (1804)|| || [[André Grétry|Grétry]], [[Étienne Méhul|Méhul]], [[Gaspare Spontini|Spontini]] || <ref name=OD /><ref>Bartlet, M Elizabeth C: ''Fait historique'' in ''[[The New Grove Dictionary of Opera]]'', ed. Stanley Sadie (London, 1992) {{ISBN|0-333-73432-7}}</ref> |- | [[Farsa]] (plural ''farse'')|| Italian || ''Literally'', 'farce'. A form of one-act opera, sometimes with dancing, associated with [[Venice]], especially the [[Teatro San Moisè]], in the late 18th and early 19th centuries. || || ''[[La cambiale di matrimonio]]'' (1810), ''[[L'inganno felice]]'' (1812), ''[[La scala di seta]]'' (1812), ''[[Il signor Bruschino]]'' (1813), ''[[Adina (opera)|Adina]]'' (1818) || || [[Gioachino Rossini|Rossini]]|| <ref name=DB>Bryant, David (1992): ''Farsa'' in ''[[The New Grove Dictionary of Opera]]'', ed. Stanley Sadie (London) {{ISBN|0-333-73432-7}}</ref> |- | [[Opera buffa]] (plural, ''opere buffe'') || Italian || Major genre of comic opera in the 18th and early 19th centuries. Originating in [[Naples]] (especially the [[Teatro dei Fiorentini]]), its popularity spread during the 1730s, notably to [[Venice]] where development was influenced by the playwright/librettist [[Carlo Goldoni|Goldoni]]. Typically in three acts, unlike the [[Intermezzo#Opera intermezzo|intermezzo]]. Contrasting in style, subject matter, and the use of dialect with the formal, aristocratic [[opera seria]]. ||{{Hs|1706}}''La Cilla'' (Michelangelo Faggioli, 1706) || ''[[Li zite 'ngalera]]'' (1722), ''Il filosofo di campagna'' ([[Baldassare Galuppi|Galuppi]], 1754), ''[[La buona figliuola]]'' (1760), ''[[Le nozze di Figaro]]'' (1786), ''[[Il barbiere di Siviglia]]'' (1816), ''[[Don Pasquale]]'' (1843) ||{{Hs|1850}}''[[Crispino e la comare]]'' (1850)|| [[Leonardo Vinci|Vinci]], [[Baldassare Galuppi|Galuppi]], [[Egidio Duni|Duni]], [[Niccolò Piccinni|Piccinni]], [[Antonio Sacchini|Sacchini]], [[Antonio Salieri|Salieri]], [[Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart|Mozart]], [[Gioachino Rossini|Rossini]] || <ref name=PW /> |- | [[Opéra bouffe]] (plural, ''opéras bouffes'') ||French || Comic genre of [[operetta|opérette]] including satire, parody and farce. Stanley Sadie (London, 1992) {{ISBN|0-333-73432-7}}</ref> |- | [[Opéra comique]] (plural, ''opéras comiques'') ||French || ''Literally'', 'comic opera'. Genre including [[aria]]s, a certain amount of spoken dialogue (and sometimes recitatives). Closely associated with works written for the [[Paris]] [[Opéra-Comique]]. Themes included were serious and tragic, as well as light. Tradition developed from popular early 18th century [[Comédie en vaudeville|comédies en vaudevilles]] and lasted into 20th century with many changes in style. ||{{Hs|1715}}''Télémaque'' (Jean-Claude Gillier, 1715) || ''[[Les troqueurs]]'' (1753), ''[[La dame blanche]]'' (1825), ''[[Carmen]]'' (1875), ''[[Lakmé]]'' (1883)|| || [[François-André Danican Philidor|Philidor]], [[Pierre-Alexandre Monsigny|Monsigny]], [[André Grétry|Grétry]], [[François-Adrien Boieldieu|Boieldieu]], [[Daniel Auber|Auber]], || <ref name=OD /> |- | {{Anchor|Opéra comique en vaudeville}}Opéra comique en vaudeville || French || ''alternative name for'' [[comédie en vaudeville]]|| || || || || |- | [[Opéra féerie]] (plural, ''opéras féeries'') ||French || 18th/19th century genre of works based on fairy tales, often involving magic. || || ''[[Zémire et Azor]]'' (1771), ''[[Cendrillon (Isouard)|Cendrillon]]'' (1810), ''[[La belle au bois dormant (opera)|La belle au bois dormant]]'' (1825) || || [[Michele Carafa|Carafa]], [[Nicolas Isouard|Isouard]] || <ref>Bartlet, M Elizabeth C: ''Opéra féerie'' in ''[[The New Grove Dictionary of Opera]]'', ed. Late 18th/19th century, less grandiose than grand opéra, but without the spoken dialogue of [[opéra comique]]. Typically included a basso buffo role. ||{{Hs|1799}}''Camilla'' ([[Ferdinando Paer|Paer]], 1799) || ''[[La gazza ladra]]'' (1817), ''[[Linda di Chamounix]]'' (1842) ||{{Hs|1853}}''Violetta'' ([[Saverio Mercadante|Mercadante]], 1853)|| [[Ferdinando Paer|Paer]], [[Gioachino Rossini|Rossini]], [[Gaetano Donizetti|Donizetti]] || <ref>[[Julian Budden|Budden, Julian]]: "Opera semiseria" in ''[[The New Grove Dictionary of Opera]]'', ed. Dominant style of opera in the 18th century, not only in Italy but throughout Europe (except [[France]]). Rigorously formal works using texts, mainly based on ancient history, by poet-librettists led by [[Metastasio]]. Patronized by the court and the nobility. Pinafore]]'' (1878), ''[[The Pirates of Penzance]]'' (1880), ''[[The Mikado]]'' (1885), ''[[The Gondoliers]]'' (1889), ''[[Merrie England (opera)|Merrie England]]'' (1902)||{{Hs|1903}}''[[A Princess of Kensington]]'' (1903)|| [[Arthur Sullivan|Sullivan]], [[Edward Solomon|Solomon]], [[Edward German|German]]||<ref name="Michael Kennedy 2006"/> |- | {{Anchor|Saynète}}Saynète ||French || ''French for'' sainete. Description used for a particular style of [[operetta|opérette]] in the 19th century.|| || ''La caravane de l'amour'' ([[Hervé (composer)|Hervé]], 1854), ''Le rêve d'une nuit d'été'' ([[Jacques Offenbach|Offenbach]], 1855), ''Le valet de coeur'' ([[Robert Planquette|Planquette]], 1875) || || [[Hervé (composer)|Hervé]], [[Jacques Offenbach|Offenbach]], [[Robert Planquette|Planquette]] || <ref name=RA /> |- | {{Anchor|Schauspiel mit Gesang}}Schauspiel mit Gesang || German || ''Literally'', 'play with singing'. Term used by [[Johann Wolfgang von Goethe|Goethe]] for his early libretti, though he called them [[Singspiel]]e when revising them. ||{{Hs|1775}}''Erwin und Elmire'' ([[Johann Wolfgang von Goethe|Goethe]] 1775)|| ''Liebe nur beglückt'' ([[Johann Friedrich Reichardt|Reichardt]], 1781), ''Die Teufels Mühle am Wienerberg'' ([[Wenzel Müller|Müller]] 1799) || || ||<ref name=BT>Bauman, Thomas (1992), 'Singspiel' in ''[[The New Grove Dictionary of Opera]]'', ed. Stanley Sadie (London) {{ISBN|0-333-73432-7}}</ref> |- | {{Anchor|Schuloper}}Schuloper || German || ''Literally'', 'school opera'. Early 20th century, opera created for performance by school children. || || ''[[Der Jasager]]'' (1930), ''Wir bauen eine Stadt'' ([[Paul Hindemith|Hindemith]], 1930) || || [[Kurt Weill|Weill]], [[Paul Hindemith|Hindemith]] || <ref>Kemp, Ian (1992), 'Schuloper' in ''[[The New Grove Dictionary of Opera]]'', ed. Stanley Sadie (London) {{ISBN|0-333-73432-7}}</ref> |- | [[Semi-opera]] || English ||Early form of [[opera]] with singing, speaking and dancing roles. Popular between 1673 and 1710.||{{Hs|1674}}''The Tempest'' ([[Thomas Betterton|Betterton]], 1674) ||''[[Psyche (Locke)|Psyche]]'' (1675), ''[[King Arthur (opera)|King Arthur]]'' (1691), ''[[The Fairy-Queen]]'' (1692) || || [[Henry Purcell|Purcell]]|| <ref name=OD /> |- | {{Anchor|Sepolcro}}Sepolcro || Italian || Azione sacra on the subject of the passion and crucifixion of Christ. || || || || [[Antonio Draghi|Draghi]] || <ref name=HS /> |- | [[Serenata]] || Italian || ''Literally'', 'evening song'. Short opera performed at court for celebrations, similar to the [[azione teatrale]]. (Also used to refer to [[serenade]]s.) || || ''[[Acis and Galatea (Handel)|Acis and Galatea]]'' (1720), ''Il Parnaso confuso'' ([[Christoph Willibald Gluck|Gluck]] 1765)|| ||[[George Frideric Handel|Handel]], [[Christoph Willibald Gluck|Gluck]] ||<ref name=OD /> |- | [[Singspiel]] (plural ''Singspiele'') ||German || ''Literally'', 'sing play'. Popular genre of the 18th/19th centuries, (though the term is also found as early as the 16th century). Derived originally from translations of [[English language|English]] [[ballad opera]]s, but also influenced by French [[opéra comique]]. Spoken [[dialogue]], combined with [[Musical ensemble|ensembles]], folk-coloured [[ballad]]s and [[aria]]s. Originally performed by traveling troupes. Plots generally comic or romantic, often including [[magic (paranormal)|magic]]. Developed into German 'rescue opera' and [[romantische Oper]].||{{Hs|1752}}''Der Teufel ist los'' (Johann Georg Standfuss, 1752) || ''[[Die verwandelten Weiber]]'' (1766), ''[[Die Jagd]]'' (1770), ''[[Die Entführung aus dem Serail]]'' (1782), ''[[Abu Hassan]]'' (1811) || || [[Johann Adam Hiller|Hiller]], [[Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart|Mozart]], [[Carl Maria von Weber|Weber]]|| <ref name=OD /><ref name=BT /> |- | {{Anchor|Situationsposse}}Situationsposse || German || Specialized form of [[Posse mit Gesang]] concentrating on social situations. || || || || ||<ref name=OD /> |- | {{Anchor|Songspiel}}Songspiel || German || ''Literally'', 'song play' ("Song" being the English word ''as used in German'', e.g. by Brecht, etc.) Term invented by [[Kurt Weill]] to update the concept of [[Singspiel]] || || ''[[Mahagonny-Songspiel]]'' (1927)|| || [[Kurt Weill]] ||<ref name=OD /> |- | [[Spieloper]] || German || ''Literally'', 'opera play'. 19th-century light opera genre, derived from [[Singspiel]] and to a lesser extent [[opéra comique]], containing spoken dialogue. [[Fach#Spieltenor / Tenor Buffo|Spieltenor]] and [[Fach#Spielbass / Bassbuffo|Spielbass]] are specialized voice types connected with the genre. || || ''[[Zar und Zimmermann]]'' (1837), ''[[The Merry Wives of Windsor (opera)|The Merry Wives of Windsor]]'' (1849) || || [[Albert Lortzing|Lortzing]], [[Otto Nicolai|Nicolai]] || <ref name=OD /> |- | {{Anchor|Syngespil}}Syngespil || Danish || Local form of [[Singspiel]]. Late 18th/19th century. || || ''Soliman den Anden'' ([[Giuseppe Sarti|Sarti]], 1770), ''[[Holger Danske (opera)|Holger Danske]]'' (1787), ''Høstgildet'' ([[Johann Abraham Peter Schulz|Schulz]], 1790) || ||[[Giuseppe Sarti|Sarti]], [[Johann Abraham Peter Schulz|Schulz]], [[F.L.Æ. Kunzen|Kunzen]] || <ref name=OD /> |- | {{Anchor|Television operas}}Television opera || English || Works written ''specifically'' for the medium of television. || ''[[Amahl and the Night Visitors]]'' (1951) || ''[[The Marriage (opera)|The Marriage]]'' (1953), ''[[Owen Wingrave]]'' (1971), ''[[Man on the Moon (opera)|Man on the Moon]]'' (2006) || || [[Gian Carlo Menotti|Menotti]], [[Bohuslav Martinů|Martinů]], [[Heinrich Sutermeister|Sutermeister]], [[Benjamin Britten|Britten]] || <ref>Salter, Lionel (1992), 'Television' in ''[[The New Grove Dictionary of Opera]]'', ed. Stanley Sadie (London) {{ISBN|0-333-73432-7}}</ref> |- | [[Tonadilla]] || Spanish || ''Literally'', 'little tune'. 18th century miniature satirical genre, for one or more singer, that developed out of the sainete. Performed in between longer works.|| || ''La mesonera y el arriero'' ([[Luis Misón]], 1757) || || Antonio Guerrero, [[Luis Misón|Misón]], José Palomino|| <ref name=OD /> |- | {{Anchor|Tragédie}}Tragédie || French || ''alternative name for'' [[tragédie en musique]]|| || || || || <ref name=GS /> |- | [[Tragédie en musique]] ||French || 17th/18th century lyric genre with themes from [[Classical mythology]] and the Italian epics of [[Torquato Tasso|Tasso]] and [[Ludovico Ariosto|Ariosto]], not necessarily with tragic outcomes. Usually 5 acts, sometimes with a prologue. Short arias (''petits airs'') contrast with dialogue in recitative, with choral sections and dancing.||{{Hs|1673}}''[[Cadmus et Hermione]]'' (1673)|| ''[[Médée (Charpentier)|Médée]]'' (1693), ''[[Scylla et Glaucus]]'' (1746)|| || [[Jean-Baptiste Lully|Lully]], [[Marin Marais|Marais]], [[Michel Pignolet de Montéclair|Montéclair]], [[André Campra|Campra]], [[Jean-Philippe Rameau|Rameau]] || <ref name=OD /><ref name=GS /> |- | {{Anchor|Tragédie lyrique}}Tragédie lyrique || French || ''alternative name for'' [[tragédie en musique]]|| || || || || <ref name=GS /> |- | {{Anchor|Tragédie mise en musique}}Tragédie mise en musique || French || ''alternative name for'' [[tragédie en musique]] || || || || || <ref name=GS /> |- | {{Anchor|Tragédie-opéra}}Tragédie-opéra || French || ''alternative name for'' [[tragédie en musique]]|| || || || || <ref name=GS /> |- | [[Verismo]] || Italian || Late 19th/early 20th century opera movement inspired by literary naturalism and realism, and associated with Italian post-romanticism.||{{Hs|1890}}''[[Cavalleria rusticana]]'' (1890)|| ''[[Pagliacci]]'' (1892), ''[[Tosca]]'' (1900) || || [[Pietro Mascagni|Mascagni]], [[Ruggiero Leoncavallo|Leoncavallo]], [[Giacomo Puccini|Puccini]], [[Umberto Giordano|Giordano]]|| <ref name=OD /> |- | {{Anchor|Volksmärchen}}Volksmärchen || German || ''alternative name for'' Märchenoper.|| || ''Das Donauweibchen'' ([[Ferdinand Kauer|Kauer]] 1798) || || || <ref name=BM/> |- | [[Zarzuela]] || Spanish || Dating back to the 17th century and forward to the present day, this form includes both singing and spoken dialogue, also dance. Local traditions are also found in [[Cuba]] and the [[Philippines]].||{{Hs|1629}}''La selva sin amor'' ([[Lope de Vega]], 1627) || [[Doña Francisquita]] (1923), [[La dolorosa]] (1930), [[Luisa Fernanda (zarzuela)|Luisa Fernanda]] (1932)|| || [[Juan Hidalgo de Polanco|Hidalgo]], [[Francisco Asenjo Barbieri|Barbieri]] || <ref name=OD /> |- | {{Anchor|Zauberoper}}Zauberoper || German || ''Literally'', 'magic opera'. Late 18th and early 19th centuries, particularly associated with Vienna. Heavier, more formal work than Zauberposse, but also with spoken dialogue. ||{{Hs|1789}}''Oberon, König der Elfen'' ([[Pavel Wranitzky|Wranitzky]], 1789) || ''[[Die Zauberflöte]]'' (1791), ''Das Donauweibchen'', ([[Ferdinand Kauer|Kauer]], 1798)|| || [[Ferdinand Kauer|Kauer]], [[Wenzel Müller|Müller]], [[Franz Schubert|Schubert]]||<ref name=OD /> |- | {{Anchor|Zauberposse}}Zauberposse || German || Specialized form of [[Posse mit Gesang]] concentrating on magic. || || ''Der Barometermacher auf der Zauberinsel'' ([[Wenzel Müller|Müller]] 1823)|| || [[Wenzel Müller|Müller]] ||<ref name=OD /> |- | [[Zeitoper]] (plural ''Zeitopern'')|| German || ''Literally'', 'opera of the times'. 1920s, early 1930s genre, using contemporary settings and characters, including references to modern technology and popular music. || || ''[[Jonny spielt auf]]'' (1927), ''[[Neues vom Tage]]'' (1929)|| || [[Ernst Krenek|Krenek]], [[Kurt Weill|Weill]], [[Paul Hindemith|Hindemith]] || <ref>Sadie, Stanley (ed) (1992), 'Zeitoper' in ''[[The New Grove Dictionary of Opera]]'', ed. Stanley Sadie (London) {{ISBN|0-333-73432-7}}</ref> |- | {{Anchor|Zwischenspiel}}Zwischenspiel || German || German name for [[Intermezzo#Opera intermezzo|intermezzo]] || || [[Pimpinone]] (1725) || || || <ref name=OD /> |}

The following '''lists of endangered languages''' are mainly based on [[Endangered language#UNESCO definitions|the definitions used by UNESCO]]. In order to be listed, a language must be classified as "endangered" in a cited academic source. Researchers have concluded that in less than one hundred years, almost half of the languages known today will be lost forever.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/09/19/science/19language.html|title=Languages Die, but Not Their Last Words|last=Wilford|first=John Noble|date=2007-09-19|newspaper=The New York Times|access-date=2017-02-10|issn=0362-4331}}</ref> * Afro-Eurasian languages ** African languages *** [[List of endangered languages in Africa]] ** Eurasian languages *** Asian languages **** [[List of endangered languages in Asia]] ***** [[List of endangered languages in Bangladesh]] ***** [[List of endangered languages in China]] ***** [[List of endangered languages in India]] ***** [[List of endangered languages in Indonesia]] ***** [[List of endangered languages in Nepal]] *** European languages **** [[List of endangered languages in Europe]] *** Russian languages **** [[List of endangered languages in Russia]] * Australian languages ** [[List of Australian Aboriginal languages]] ** [[List of endangered languages in Papua New Guinea]] * North and South American languages ** [[List of endangered languages in North America]] *** [[List of endangered languages in Canada]] *** [[List of endangered languages in Central America]] *** [[List of endangered languages in Mexico]] *** [[List of endangered languages in the United States]] ** [[List of endangered languages in South America]] *** [[List of endangered languages in Brazil]] *** [[List of endangered languages in Colombia]] * Pacific languages ** [[List of endangered languages of the Pacific]]
[[SIL Ethnologue]] (2005) lists 473 out of 6,909 living languages inventorized (6.8%) as "nearly extinct", indicating cases where "only a few elderly speakers are still living"; this figure dropped to 6.1% as of 2013.<ref>Lewis, M. Paul, Gary F. Simons, and Charles D. Fennig (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition. Dallas, Texas: SIL International. Online version: [http://www.ethnologue.com/statistics/status Summary by language status]</ref>
In order to judge if a language is endangered, the number of speakers is less important than their age distribution. There are languages in [[Indonesia]] reported with as many as two million native speakers alive now, but all of advancing age, with little or no transmission to the young. On the other hand, while there are only 30,000 [[Ladin language|Ladin]] speakers left, almost all children still learn it as their mother tongue, thus Ladin is not currently endangered. Similarly, the [[Hawaiian language]] has only about 1,000 speakers but it has stabilized at this number, and there is now school instruction in the language, from preschool through the 12th grade. Thus the language is classified as merely vulnerable.
While there are somewhere around six or seven thousand languages on Earth today, about half of them have fewer than about 3,000 speakers. Experts predict that even in a conservative scenario, about half of today's languages will become extinct within the next fifty to one hundred years.

{{EngvarB|date=September 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2013}} {{Infobox writer <!-- for more information see [[:Template:Infobox writer/doc]] --> | name = Mick Paynter | image = Mick Paynter.jpg | caption = Paynter as ''Skogynn Pryv'' | birth_date = 1948 | birth_name = Michael Kenneth Paynter | birth_place = [[Redruth]], [[Cornwall]] | death_date = | death_place = | occupation = [[Civil servant]] | genre = Cornish Language | movement = | net worth = | influences = | influenced = | website = | spouse = | children = |signature = }}
'''Michael Kenneth (Mick) Paynter''' (born 1948, [[Cornwall]], United Kingdom) is a retired [[Cornwall|Cornish]] civil servant, trade union activist, and poet. Apart from a period of study at the [[Newcastle University|University of Newcastle]], his home has always been in [[St Ives, Cornwall|St Ives]] (Cornish ''Porthia'').
He is a member of [[Gorseth Kernow]], and was initiated as a [[bard]] under the [[Bardic name]] ''Skogynn Pryv'' (Worm's Fool) in 2003 on passing a [[Cornish language]] examination after four years of study, largely conducted during train journeys as a trade union representative. The name derives from the nickname of a [[smuggling|smuggler's]] assistant in a local story involving outwitting a Customs man, and was chosen as appropriate as he worked for 32 years in the [[Inland Revenue]]. He was Deputy Grand Bard from September 2006, and was installed as Grand Bard in September 2009 until he handed over to Maureen Fuller (Steren Mor) at the end of the Camelford Gorsedd on 1 September 2012. Member of the Cornish Language Board (Kesva an Taves Kernewek) 2006-2015. Chairman Bewnans Kernow 2009-2012,Treasurer Bewnans Kernow 2012-2016.
As well as contributions to anthologies, he has written three collections of poetry in Cornish with English translations, and is Cornish Language Editor of ''[[Poetry Cornwall / Bardhonyaeth Kernow]]''. His poetry combines the easy flow of colloquial [[Cornish language|Cornish]] with a variety of influences ranging from Afro-American song to [[Primo Levi]] and early Celtic literature.{{Citation needed|date=August 2007}} He is a frequent contributor to magazines such as ''[[Scryfa]]'' and ''Poetry Cornwall / Bardhonyeth Kernow''. His collection "A Worm's Folly" received a nomination in the 2012 Holyer An Gof literary awards. He was elected President St Ives Old Cornwall Society at its 2014 AGM and continued until the AGM 2017, he was succeeded by Margaret Stevens.

revision.text:
'''[[Old Church Slavonic]]''' is an [[inflectional language]] with moderately complex verbal and nominal systems. ==Nouns== The nominal case category distinguishes 7 cases for nouns, 6 for pronouns and adjectives (no vocative): {| class="wikitable" |+ Nominal cases |- | Abbr. | Case |- | [[Nominative|N]] | [[Nominative]] |- | [[Genitive|G]] | [[Genitive]] |- | [[Dative|D]] | [[Dative]] |- | [[Accusative|A]] | [[Accusative]] |- | [[Vocative|V]] | [[Vocative]] |- | [[Locative|L]] | [[Locative]] |- | [[Instrumental case|I]] | [[Instrumental case|Instrumental]] |} ===o-stems=== {{col-begin}} {{col-break|width=15em}} {| class="wikitable" |+ Masculine gender ("town") |- | - | Singular | Dual | Plural |- | [[Nominative|N]] | grad-'''ъ''' | grad-'''a''' | grad-'''i''' |- | [[Genitive|G]] | grad-'''a''' | grad-'''u''' | grad-'''ъ''' |- | [[Dative|D]] | grad-'''u''' | grad-'''oma''' | grad-'''omъ''' |- | [[Accusative|A]] | grad-'''ъ''' | grad-'''a''' | grad-'''y''' |- | [[Vocative|V]] | grad-'''e''' | grad-'''a''' | grad-'''i''' |- | [[Locative|L]] | grad-'''ě''' | grad-'''u''' | grad-'''ěxъ''' |- | [[Instrumental case|I]] | grad-'''omь''' | grad-'''oma''' | grad-'''y''' |} {{col-break|valign=middle|gap=1em}} Nouns belonging to this declension class are generally masculines ending in '''''-ъ''''' in the nominative singular (''bogъ'', ''gradъ'', ''rodъ''). The only exception are the nouns in ''-ъ'' that inflect as u-stem masculines. Sometimes (but not yet obligatorily, in contrast to later Slavic languages), in the accusative singular, the beginnings of a difference between an animate and inanimate subgender can be seen, as the genitive may occasionally be used instead of the accusative for animate objects (''raba'' beside ''rabъ'').
Nouns with the suffix '''''-(j)an-in-ъ''''' (''graždaninъ'') also belong to this declension class in the singular, but in the plural they lose the ''-in-'' interfix and conform to the consonantal paradigm (''graždane, graždanъ, graždanem, graždany, graždane, graždanexъ, graždany). {{col-end}} {{col-begin}} {{col-break|width=15em}} {| class="wikitable" |+ Neuter gender ("wine") |- | - | Singular | Dual | Plural |- | [[Nominative|N]] | vin-'''o''' | vin-'''ě''' | vin-'''a''' |- | [[Genitive|G]] | vin-'''a''' | vin-'''u''' | vin-'''ъ''' |- | [[Dative|D]] | vin-'''u''' | vin-'''oma''' | vin-'''omъ''' |- | [[Accusative|A]] | vin-'''o''' | vin-'''ě''' | vin-'''a''' |- | [[Vocative|V]] | vin-'''o''' | vin-'''ě''' | vin-'''a''' |- | [[Locative|L]] | vin-'''ě''' | vin-'''u''' | vin-'''ěxъ''' |- | [[Instrumental case|I]] | vin-'''omь''' | vin-'''oma''' | vin-'''y''' |} {{col-break|valign=middle|gap=1em}} Nouns belonging to this declension class are neuters ending in '''''-o''''' in the nominative singular (''selo'', ''lěto'', ''město''). The only exception are the few neuters that are inflected as s-stems. {{col-end}} ===jo-stems=== {{col-begin}} {{col-break|width=15em}} {| class="wikitable" |+ Masculine gender ("knife") |- | - | Singular | Dual | Plural |- | [[Nominative|N]] | nož-'''ь''' | nož-'''a''' | nož-'''i''' |- | [[Genitive|G]] | nož-'''a''' | nož-'''u''' | nož-'''ь''' |- | [[Dative|D]] | nož-'''u''' | nož-'''ema''' | nož-'''emъ''' |- | [[Accusative|A]] | nož-'''ь''' | nož-'''a''' | nož-'''ę''' |- | [[Vocative|V]] | nož-'''u''' | nož-'''a''' | nož-'''i''' |- | [[Locative|L]] | nož-'''i''' | nož-'''u''' | nož-'''ixъ''' |- | [[Instrumental case|I]] | nož-'''emь''' | nož-'''ema''' | nož-'''i''' |} {{col-break|valign=middle|gap=1em}} Nouns belonging to this declension class are masculines ending in '''''-ь''''' preceded by a [[palatal]] in the nominative singular (''vračь'', ''kralь'', ''košь''). This paradigm encompasses nouns such as ''krai'' that don't appear to be ending in a palatal, but are in fact underlyingly combinations like ''krajь'' and so undergo this declension (''kraj -ь'', ''kraj -a''). Nouns ending in agentive suffixes '''''-tel-ь''''' and '''''-ar-ь''''' also belong to this class (''učitelь, učitelja, učitelju...'', ''mytarь, mytarja, mytarju...''). {{col-end}} {{col-begin}} {{col-break|width=15em}} {| class="wikitable" |+ Neuter gender ("sea") |- | - | Singular | Dual | Plural |- | [[Nominative|N]] | mor-'''e''' | mor-'''i''' | mor-'''a''' |- | [[Genitive|G]] | mor-'''a''' | mor-'''u''' | mor-'''ь''' |- | [[Dative|D]] | mor-'''u''' | mor-'''ema''' | mor-'''emъ''' |- | [[Accusative|A]] | mor-'''e''' | mor-'''i''' | mor-'''a''' |- | [[Vocative|V]] | mor-'''e''' | mor-'''i''' | mor-'''a''' |- | [[Locative|L]] | mor-'''i''' | mor-'''u''' | mor-'''ixъ''' |- | [[Instrumental case|I]] | mor-'''emь''' | mor-'''ema''' | mor-'''i''' |} {{col-break|valign=middle|gap=1em}} The jo-stem declension class encompasses neuters ending in ''-e'' (''lože'', ''polje'', ''molenьe''). {{col-end}} ===a-stems=== {{col-begin}} {{col-break|width=15em}} {| class="wikitable" |+ Feminine gender ("hand/arm") |- | - | Singular | Dual | Plural |- | [[Nominative|N]] | rǫk-'''a''' | rǫ'''c'''-'''ě''' | rǫk-'''y''' |- | [[Genitive|G]] | rǫk-'''y''' | rǫk-'''u''' | rǫk-'''ъ''' |- | [[Dative|D]] | rǫ'''c'''-'''ě''' | rǫk-'''ama''' | rǫk-'''amъ''' |- | [[Accusative|A]] | rǫk-'''ǫ''' | rǫ'''c'''-'''ě''' | rǫk-'''y''' |- | [[Vocative|V]] | rǫk-'''o''' | rǫ'''c'''-'''ě''' | rǫk-'''y''' |- | [[Locative|L]] | rǫ'''c'''-'''ě''' | rǫk-'''u''' | rǫk-'''axъ''' |- | [[Instrumental case|I]] | rǫk-'''ojǫ''' | rǫk-'''ama''' | rǫk-'''ami''' |} {{col-break|valign=middle|gap=1em}} Nouns belonging to this declension class are feminines ending in '''''-a''''' preceded by a hard, non-palatal consonant (''žena''). Also belonging to this paradigm are the rare masculines ending in ''-a'' (''sluga'', ''vojevoda''). {{col-end}} ===ja-stems=== {{col-begin}} {{col-break|width=15em}} {| class="wikitable" |+ Feminine gender ("soul") |- | - | Singular | Dual | Plural |- | [[Nominative|N]] | duš-'''a''' | duš-'''i''' | duš-'''ę''' |- | [[Genitive|G]] | duš-'''ę''' | duš-'''u''' | duš-'''ь''' |- | [[Dative|D]] | duš-'''i''' | duš-'''ama''' | duš-'''amъ''' |- | [[Accusative|A]] | duš-'''ǫ''' | duš-'''i''' | duš-'''ę''' |- | [[Vocative|V]] | duš-'''e''' | duš-'''i''' | duš-'''ę''' |- | [[Locative|L]] | duš-'''i''' | duš-'''u''' | duš-'''axъ''' |- | [[Instrumental case|I]] | duš-'''ejǫ''' | duš-'''ama''' | duš-'''ami''' |} {{col-break|valign=middle|gap=1em}} Noun belonging to this declension class are feminines ending in '''''-a''''' preceded by a soft, palatal consonant (''straža'', ''svešta'', ''mrěža''). This paradigm also encompasses feminines ending in '''''-i''''' (''rabyni'', ''bogyni''), '''''-ica''''' (''děvica'') and '''''-ьni-''''' (''rizьnica''), and also masculines ending in ''-a'' preceded by a palatal (''junoša''). {{col-end}} ===i-stems=== {{col-begin}} {{col-break|width=15em}} {| class="wikitable" |+ Masculine gender ("guest") |- | - | Singular | Dual | Plural |- | [[Nominative|N]] | gost-'''ь''' | gost-'''i''' | gost-'''ьje''' |- | [[Genitive|G]] | gost-'''i''' | gost-'''ьju''' | gost-'''ьi''' |- | [[Dative|D]] | gost-'''i''' | gost-'''ьma''' | gost-'''ьmъ''' |- | [[Accusative|A]] | gost-'''ь''' | gost-'''i''' | gost-'''i''' |- | [[Vocative|V]] | gost-'''i''' | gost-'''i''' | gost-'''ьje''' |- | [[Locative|L]] | gost-'''i''' | gost-'''ьju''' | gost-'''ьxъ''' |- | [[Instrumental case|I]] | gost-'''ьmь''' | gost-'''ьma''' | gost-'''ьmi''' |} {{col-break|valign=middle|gap=1em}} Nouns belonging to this declension class are masculines ending in '''''-ь''''' preceded by a hard, non-palatal consonant (''črьvь'', ''gospodь'', ''pǫtь''). The only exception are a limited number of such nouns belonging to the n-stem paradigm. {{col-end}} {{col-begin}} {{col-break|width=15em}} {| class="wikitable" |+ Feminine gender ("bone") |- | - | Singular | Dual | Plural |- | [[Nominative|N]] | kost-'''ь''' | kost-'''i''' | kost-'''i''' |- | [[Genitive|G]] | kost-'''i''' | kost-'''ьju''' | kost-'''ьi''' |- | [[Dative|D]] | kost-'''i''' | kost-'''ьma''' | kost-'''ьmъ''' |- | [[Accusative|A]] | kost-'''ь''' | kost-'''i''' | kost-'''i''' |- | [[Vocative|V]] | kost-'''i''' | kost-'''i''' | kost-'''i''' |- | [[Locative|L]] | kost-'''i''' | kost-'''ьju''' | kost-'''ьxъ''' |- | [[Instrumental case|I]] | kost-'''ьjǫ''' | kost-'''ьma''' | kost-'''ьmi''' |} {{col-break|valign=middle|gap=1em}} Nouns belonging to the i-stem feminine declension are feminines ending in '''''-ь''''' in the nominative singular (''rěčь, ''noštь'', ''tvarь''). The only exception is the noun ''krъvь'' which undergoes ъv-stem (ū-stem) declension. {{col-end}} ===u-stems=== {{col-begin}} {{col-break|width=15em}} {| class="wikitable" |+ Masculine gender ("house") |- | - | Singular | Dual | Plural |- | [[Nominative|N]] | dom-'''ъ''' | dom-'''y''' | dom-'''ove''' |- | [[Genitive|G]] | dom-'''u''' | dom-'''ovu''' | dom-'''ovъ''' |- | [[Dative|D]] | dom-'''ovi''' | dom-'''ъma''' | dom-'''ъmъ''' |- | [[Accusative|A]] | dom-'''ъ''' | dom-'''y''' | dom-'''y''' |- | [[Vocative|V]] | dom-'''u''' | dom-'''y''' | dom-'''ove''' |- | [[Locative|L]] | dom-'''u''' | dom-'''ovu''' | dom-'''ъxъ''' |- | [[Instrumental case|I]] | dom-'''ъmь''' | dom-'''ъma''' | dom-'''ъmi''' |} {{col-break|valign=middle|gap=1em}} Nouns belonging to this declension are a rather small group of masculines: '''činъ''', '''domъ''', '''ledъ''', '''medъ''', '''mirъ''', '''polъ''', '''sanъ''', '''synъ''', '''volъ''', '''vrъxъ'''. {{col-end}} ===ū-stems=== {{col-begin}} {{col-break|width=15em}} {| class="wikitable" |+ Feminine gender |- | - | Singular | Dual | Plural |- | [[Nominative|N]] | tik-'''y''' | tik'''ъv'''-'''i''' | tik'''ъv'''-'''i''' |- | [[Genitive|G]] | tik'''ъv'''-'''e''' | tik'''ъv'''-'''u''' | tik'''ъv'''-'''ъ''' |- | [[Dative|D]] | tik'''ъv'''-'''i''' | tik'''ъv'''-'''ama''' | tik'''ъv'''-'''amъ''' |- | [[Accusative|A]] | tik'''ъv'''-'''ь''' | tik'''ъv'''-'''i''' | tik'''ъv'''-'''i''' |- | [[Vocative|V]] | tik-'''y''' | tik'''ъv'''-'''i''' | tik'''ъv'''-'''i''' |- | [[Locative|L]] | tik'''ъv'''-'''e''' | tik'''ъv'''-'''u''' | tik'''ъv'''-'''axъ''' |- | [[Instrumental case|I]] | tik'''ъv'''-'''ьjǫ''' | tik'''ъv'''-'''ama''' | tik'''ъv'''-'''ami''' |} {{col-break|valign=middle|gap=1em}} Nouns belonging to the ū-stem declension (also known as '''-ъv-''' declension, or '''v-stem''' declension) are: '''buky''', '''brady''', '''cěly''', '''crьky''', '''horǫgy''', '''loky''', '''ljuby''', '''neplody''', '''prěljuby''', '''smoky''', '''svekry''', '''žrьny''', '''kry''' (this last form is attested in [[Psalterium Sinaiticum]]; older sources list the accusative form ''krъvь'' as a lemma). {{col-end}} ===n-stems=== {{col-begin}} {{col-break|width=15em}} {| class="wikitable" |+ Masculine gender ("stone") |- | - | Singular | Dual | Plural |- | [[Nominative|N]] | kam-'''y''' | kam'''en'''-'''i''' | kam'''en'''-'''e''' |- | [[Genitive|G]] | kam'''en'''-'''e''' | kam'''en'''-'''u''' | kam'''en'''-'''ъ''' |- | [[Dative|D]] | kam'''en'''-'''i''' | kam'''en'''-'''ьma''' | kam'''en'''-'''ьmъ''' |- | [[Accusative|A]] | kam'''en'''-'''ь''' | kam'''en'''-'''i''' | kam'''en'''-'''i''' |- | [[Vocative|V]] | kam-'''y''' | kam'''en'''-'''i''' | kam'''en'''-'''e''' |- | [[Locative|L]] | kam'''en'''-'''e''' | kam'''en'''-'''u''' | kam'''en'''-'''ьxъ''' |- | [[Instrumental case|I]] | kam'''en'''-'''ьmь''' | kam'''en'''-'''ьma''' | kam'''en'''-'''ьmi''' |} {{col-break|valign=middle|gap=1em}} Nouns belonging to this declension class are the following masculines: '''dьnь''', '''jelenь''', '''jęčьmenь''', '''kamy''', '''korenь''', '''plamy''', '''remenь''', '''sęženь''', '''stepenь'''. {{col-end}} {{col-begin}} {{col-break|width=15em}} {| class="wikitable" |+ Neuter gender ("tribe") |- | - | Singular | Dual | Plural |- | [[Nominative|N]] | plem-'''ę''' | plem'''en'''-'''i''' | plem'''en'''-'''a''' |- | [[Genitive|G]] | plem'''en'''-'''e''' | plem'''en'''-'''u''' | plem'''en'''-'''ъ''' |- | [[Dative|D]] | plem'''en'''-'''i''' | plem'''en'''-'''ьma''' | plem'''en'''-'''ьmъ''' |- | [[Accusative|A]] | plem-'''ę''' | plem'''en'''-'''i''' | plem'''en'''-'''a''' |- | [[Vocative|V]] | plem-'''ę''' | plem'''en'''-'''i''' | plem'''en'''-'''a''' |- | [[Locative|L]] | plem'''en'''-'''e''' | plem'''en'''-'''u''' | plem'''en'''-'''ьxъ''' |- | [[Instrumental case|I]] | plem'''en'''-'''ьmь''' | plem'''en'''-'''ьma''' | plem'''en'''-'''y''' |} {{col-break|valign=middle|gap=1em}} Nouns belonging to this declension class are the following neuters: '''brěmę''', '''čismę''', '''imę''', '''pismę''', '''plemę''', '''sěmę''', '''slěmę''', '''těmę''', '''vrěmę'''. {{col-end}} ===s-stems=== {{col-begin}} {{col-break|width=15em}} {| class="wikitable" |+ Neuter gender ("sky/heaven") |- | - | Singular | Dual | Plural |- | [[Nominative|N]] | neb-'''o''' | neb'''es'''-'''ě''' | neb'''es'''-'''a''' |- | [[Genitive|G]] | neb'''es'''-'''e''' | neb'''es'''-'''u''' | neb'''es'''-'''ъ''' |- | [[Dative|D]] | neb'''es'''-'''i''' | neb'''es'''-'''ьma''' | neb'''es'''-'''ьmъ''' |- | [[Accusative|A]] | neb-'''o''' | neb'''es'''-'''ě''' | neb'''es'''-'''a''' |- | [[Vocative|V]] | neb-'''o''' | neb'''es'''-'''ě''' | neb'''es'''-'''a''' |- | [[Locative|L]] | neb'''es'''-'''e''' | neb'''es'''-'''u''' | neb'''es'''-'''ьxъ''' |- | [[Instrumental case|I]] | neb'''es'''-'''ьmь''' | neb'''es'''-'''ьma''' | neb'''es'''-'''y''' |} {{col-break|valign=middle|gap=1em}} Nouns belonging to this declension class are the following neuters: '''čudo''', '''divo''', '''drěvo''', '''kolo''', '''nebo''', '''tělo''', '''slovo''' and also '''uxo''' and '''oko''' which have dual forms like i-stems. {{col-end}} ===t-stems=== {{col-begin}} {{col-break|width=15em}} {| class="wikitable" |+ Neuter gender ("calf") |- | - | Singular | Dual | Plural |- | [[Nominative|N]] | tel-'''ę''' | tel'''ęt'''-'''ě''' | tel'''ęt'''-'''a''' |- | [[Genitive|G]] | tel'''ęt'''-'''e''' | tel'''ęt'''-'''u''' | tel'''ęt'''-'''ъ''' |- | [[Dative|D]] | tel'''ęt'''-'''i''' | tel'''ęt'''-'''ьma''' | tel'''ęt'''-'''ьmъ''' |- | [[Accusative|A]] | tel-'''ę''' | tel'''ęt'''-'''ě''' | tel'''ęt'''-'''a''' |- | [[Vocative|V]] | tel-'''ę''' | tel'''ęt'''-'''ě''' | tel'''ęt'''-'''a''' |- | [[Locative|L]] | tel'''ęt'''-'''e''' | tel'''ęt'''-'''u''' | tel'''ęt'''-'''ьxъ''' |- | [[Instrumental case|I]] | tel'''ęt'''-'''ьmь''' | tel'''ęt'''-'''ьma''' | tel'''ęt'''-'''y''' |} {{col-break|valign=middle|gap=1em}} The t-stem (also known as '''nt'''-stem) paradigm encompasses neuters denoting a young of an animal or human: '''otročę''', '''agnę''', '''kozьlę''', '''kljusę''', '''osьlę''', '''ovьčę''', '''telę''', '''žrěbę''' etc. {{col-end}} ===r-stems=== {{col-begin}} {{col-break|width=15em}} {| class="wikitable" |+ Feminine gender ("mother") |- | - | Singular | Dual | Plural |- | [[Nominative|N]] | mat-'''i''' | mat'''er'''-'''i''' | mat'''er'''-'''i''' |- | [[Genitive|G]] | mat'''er'''-'''e''' | mat'''er'''-'''u''' | mat'''er'''-'''ъ''' |- | [[Dative|D]] | mat'''er'''-'''i''' | mat'''er'''-'''ьma''' | mat'''er'''-'''ьmъ''' |- | [[Accusative|A]] | mat'''er'''-'''ь''' | mat'''er'''-'''i''' | mat'''er'''-'''i''' |- | [[Vocative|V]] | mat-'''i''' | mat'''er'''-'''i''' | mat'''er'''-'''i''' |- | [[Locative|L]] | mat'''er'''-'''i''' | mat'''er'''-'''u''' | mat'''er'''-'''ьxъ''' |- | [[Instrumental case|I]] | mat'''er'''-'''ьjǫ''' | mat'''er'''-'''ьma''' | mat'''er'''-'''ьmi''' |} {{col-break|valign=middle|gap=1em}} r-stem feminines are the nouns '''mati''' and '''dъšti'''. {{col-end}} ==Pronouns== ===Personal pronouns=== {{col-begin}} {{col-break}} {| class="wikitable" |+ First-person pronoun |- | - | Singular | Dual | Plural |- | [[Nominative|N]] | azъ | vě | my |- | [[Genitive|G]] | mene | naju | nasъ |- | [[Dative|D]] | mьně (mi) | nama (na) | namъ (ny) |- | [[Accusative|A]] | mene (mę) | na (ny) | ny |- | [[Locative|L]] | mьně | naju | nasъ |- | [[Instrumental case|I]] | mъnojǫ | nama | nami |} {{col-break|gap=5em}} {| class="wikitable" |+ Second-person pronoun |- | - | Singular | Dual | Plural |- | [[Nominative|N]] | ty | va (vy) | vy |- | [[Genitive|G]] | tebe | vaju | vasъ |- | [[Dative|D]] | tebě (ti) | vama (va) | vamъ |- | [[Accusative|A]] | tebe (tę) | va (vy) | vasъ (vy) |- | [[Locative|L]] | tebě | vaju | vasъ |- | [[Instrumental case|I]] | tobojǫ | vama | vami |} {{col-end}} {{col-begin}} {{col-break|width=50em}} {| class="wikitable" |+ Third-person pronoun |- | - | colspan="3" align="center" | '''Singular''' | colspan="3" align="center" | '''Dual''' | colspan="3" align="center" | '''Plural''' |- | - | Masculine | Feminine | Neuter | Masculine | Feminine | Neuter | Masculine | Feminine | Neuter |- | [[Nominative|N]] | *i (jь) | *ja | *je | ja | i (ji) | i (ji) | i (ji) | ję | ja |- | [[Genitive|G]] | jego | jeję | jego | jeju | jeju | jeju | (j)ixъ | (j)ixъ | (j)ixъ |- | [[Dative|D]] | jemu | jei | jemu | (j)ima | (j)ima | (j)ima | (j)imъ | (j)imъ | (j)imъ |- | [[Accusative|A]] | i (jь), nь | jǫ | je | ja | ji | ji | ję | ję | ja |- | [[Locative|L]] | jemь | jei | jemь | jeju | jeju | jeju | (j)ixъ | (j)ixъ | (j)ixъ |- | [[Instrumental case|I]] | (j)imь | jejǫ | (j)imь | (j)ima | (j)ima | (j)ima | (j)imi | (j)imi | (j)imi |} {{col-break|valign=middle|gap=1em}} Just as the first and second person pronouns, the third person pronoun is commonly used only in oblique cases. Nominative singular forms are not attested in the OCS corpus, and are reconstructed. In the East South Slavic dialectal area where OCS originated, a suppletive nominative singular stem of the demonstrative ''tъ'' ('that') is used, elsewhere ''onъ'' ('that one there, yon'), or very rarely ''sь'' ('this'). By attaching the enclitic particle ''že'' to the forms of *i one obtains the relative pronoun: ''iže'' ('he who'), ''ježe'' ('the (female) one to whom'), ''jejuže'' ('the two of whom'), etc. When following prepositions, these pronouns take a prothetic ''n-'', hence ''kъ n'imъ'' ('to them') instead of ''*imъ'', ''na n'emь'' ('on him'), etc. This is a remnant of final -m/n in the PIE prepositions *kom (cf. Latin [[:wikt:cum#Latin|cum]], Sanskrit [[:wikt:कम्|kám]]), *sm̥ (cf. Sanskrit [[:wikt:सम्|sám]]) and *h₁n̥ that yielded the OCS prepositions ''kъ'', ''sъ'', and ''vъ'' and then spread analogically to all the other prepositions. {{col-end}} {{col-begin}} {{col-break|width=15em}} {| class="wikitable" |+Reflexive pronoun |- | - | Singular |- | [[Nominative|N]] | - |- | [[Genitive|G]] | sebe |- | [[Dative|D]] | sebě (si) |- | [[Accusative|A]] | sę |- | [[Locative|L]] | sebě |- | [[Instrumental case|I]] | sobojǫ |} {{col-break|valign=middle|gap=1em}} The reflexive pronoun has only singular oblique forms, which is the state of affairs inherited from PIE [[:wikt:Appendix:Proto-Indo-European *swé|*swé]]. The reflexive pronoun refers to the subject as a whole, and can be translated as English ''-self'' (myself, yourself, himself etc.) {{col-end}} ===Relative pronoun=== {{col-begin}} {{col-break|width=15em}} {| class="wikitable" |+ Relative pronoun |- | - | colspan="3" align="center" | '''Singular''' | colspan="3" align="center" | '''Dual''' | colspan="3" align="center" | '''Plural''' |- | - | Masculine | Feminine | Neuter | Masculine | Feminine | Neuter | Masculine | Feminine | Neuter |- | [[Nominative|N]] | iže | jaže | ježe | jaže | iže | iže | iže | jęže | jaže |- | [[Genitive|G]] | jegože | jejęže | jegože | jejuže | jejuže | jejuže | ixъže | ixъže | ixъže |- | [[Dative|D]] | jemuže | jeiže | jemuže | imaže | imaže | imaže | imъže | imъže | imъže |- | [[Accusative|A]] | iže | jǫže | ježe | jaže | iže | iže | jęže | jęže | jaže |- | [[Locative|L]] | jemьže | jeiže | jemьže | jejuže | jejuže | jejuže | ixъže | ixъže | ixъže |- | [[Instrumental case|I]] | imьže | jejǫže | imьže | imaže | imaže | imaže | imiže | imiže | imiže |} {{col-break|valign=middle|gap=1em}} As mentioned, the third person pronoun *i participates in the formation of the relative pronoun by appending the indeclinable enclitic ''že''. Unlike the third person pronoun, however, the nominative case forms do occur. Similarly, a prothetic ''n-'' occurs when following prepositions, e.g., ''vъ n'ьže'' ('in which'). {{col-end}} ===Interrogative pronoun and adjective=== {{col-begin}} {{col-break|width=15em}} {| class="wikitable" |+ Interrogative pronoun |- | - | Masculine,
Feminine | Neuter |- | [[Nominative|N]] | kъto | čьto (čь) |- | [[Genitive|G]] | kogo | česo (česogo, čьso, čьsogo) |- | [[Dative|D]] | komu | česomu (čьsomu, čemu) |- | [[Accusative|A]] | kogo | čьto |- | [[Locative|L]] | komь | čemь (česomь) |- | [[Instrumental case|I]] | cěmь | čimь |} {{col-break|valign=middle|gap=1em}} The interrogative pronoun ('who?, what?') has singular-only forms, with the masculine and feminine forms syncretized. Variant forms of ''čьto'' occurring in some of the oblique cases have been listed in parentheses. {{col-end}} {{col-begin}} {{col-break|width=15em}} {| class="wikitable" |+Interrogative adjective (pronoun) |- | - | - | cii | kyję | kaja |- | [[Genitive|G]] | kojego | kojeję (koję) | kojego | (kojeju) | (kojeju) | (kojeju) | kyixъ (koixъ) | kyixъ (koixъ) | kyixъ (koixъ) |- | [[Dative|D]] | kojemu | kojei (koi) | kojemu | kyima | kyima | kyima | kyimъ | kyimъ | kyimъ |- | [[Accusative|A]] | kyi | kǫjǫ (kojǫ) | koje | (kaja) | - | - | čiję | čiję | čija |- | [[Locative|L]] | čijemь | čijei | čijemь | (čijeju) | (čijeju) | (čijeju) | čiixъ | čiixъ | čiixъ |- | [[Instrumental case|I]] | čiimь | čijejǫ (kojǫ) | čiimь | čiima | čiima | čiima | čiimi | čiimi | čiimi |} {{col-break|valign=middle|gap=1em}} The possessive interrogative adjective, sometimes also labelled as the possessive interrogative pronoun ('whose?'), follows the same declension. {{col-end}} ===Indefinite pronouns and adjectives=== The interrogative pronouns ''kъto, čьto'' can also have the indefinite meanings of 'anybody', 'anything' respectively. The prefix ''ně-'' imparts an indefinite meaning to the word to which it is attached: thus ''kъto'' ('who?') becomes ''někъto'' ('someone'), and ''čьto'' ('what?') becomes ''něčьto'' ('something'). Similarly, the prefix ''ni-'' imparts a negative meaning: ''nikъto'' ('no one'), ''ničьto'' ('nothing'). A prepositions may come between prefix and base word: : ně u kogo — ''with someone'' : ni o komьže nerodiši — ''you care for no one'' ==Adjectives== OCS adjectives can be in two forms: '''short''' and '''long''', corresponding to '''indefinite''' and '''definite''' meaning respectively. The long form is generally used only attributively, whereas the short form is predicative in nature. So, e.g., ''člověkъ dobrъ'' "a good man, man is good" whilst ''člověkъ dobryi'' "the good man, the man who is good". Indefinite adjectives are inflected as the corresponding nouns of the primary declension, e.g., ''novъ'' as ''rabъ'', ''nova'' as ''žena'', ''novo'' as ''selo'', ''ništь'' as ''vračь'', ''ništa'' as ''duša'', ''nište'' as ''polje''. Definite adjectives (also known as '''compound''', '''long''', or '''pronominal''' forms of adjective) are formed by suffixing to the indefinite form the anaphoric third-person pronoun ''jь'' (spelled as ''i'' in OCS orthography), ''ja, je'' as shown in the table. {| class="wikitable" |- |+ "new" | [[Nominative|N]] | novъ + i (jь) = novъjь > novyi | nova + ja = novaja |- | [[Genitive|G]] | nova + jego = novajego | novy + jeję = novyję |- | [[Dative|D]] | novu + jemu = novujemu | nově + jei = nověi |- | [[Accusative|A]] | novъ + i (jь) = novъjь > novyi | novǫ + jǫ = novǫjǫ |- | [[Locative|L]] | nově + jemь = novějemь | nově + jei = nověi |- | [[Instrumental case|I]] | novomь + imь = novъimь > novyimь | novojǫ + jejǫ = novojǫ, novǫjǫ |} {| class="wikitable" |- | [[Nominative|N]], [[Accusative|A]] | nova + ja = novaja | nově + i = nověi |- | [[Genitive|G]], [[Locative|L]] | novu + jeju = novuju | novu + jeju = novuju |- | [[Dative|D]], [[Instrumental case|I]] | novoma + ima = novyima | novoma + ima = novyima |} {| class="wikitable" |- | [[Nominative|N]] | novi + (j)i = novii | novy + ję = novyję |- | [[Genitive|G]] | novъ + ixъ = novyixъ | novъ + ixъ = novyixъ |- | [[Dative|D]] | novomъ + imъ = novyimъ | novamъ + imъ = novyimъ |- | [[Accusative|A]] | novy + ję = novyję | novy + ję = novyję |- | [[Locative|L]] | nověxъ + ixъ = novyixъ | novaxъ + ixъ = novyixъ |- | [[Instrumental case|I]] | novy + imi = novyimi | novami + imi = novyimi |} ===Adjective gradation=== There are three levels of adjective gradation in OCS: *'''positive''', stating an absolute property of an object; *'''comparative''', stating a relative property of an object; *'''superlative''', stating a property of an object in relation to any other object it may be compared to. ("grumpy") − grǫblii, grǫble, grǫblьši. # Adjectives with rising tone on the root syllable: #: novъ ("new") − nov-ěi, nov-ěje, nov-ěiši; #: starъ ("old") − star-ěi, star-ěje, star-ěiši; #: junъ is formed: # by adding the prefix ''nai-'' to the comparative base: '''naidražii, naitęžьši, naigrǫble'''; # by combining the comparative form with the pronoun ''vьsego/vьsěxъ'': '''nověi vьsego, dražii vьsěxъ'''. The '''absolute superlative''' is formed: # by adding the prefix ''prě-'' to the positive: '''prědragъ, prěnova, prěstaro'''; # by using the adverb ''Ʒělo'' with the positive: '''Ʒělo dragъ, Ʒělo nova, Ʒělo staro'''. ==Numerals== ===Cardinals=== :{| | 1 |||| jedinъ (''m''), jedina (''f''), jedino (''n'') |- | 2 |||| dъva (''m''), dъvě (''f'' and ''n'') |- | 3 |||| tri (''m''), trьje (''f'' and inflected like the corresponding adjectives. ==Verbs== ===Present=== The '''present tense''' is formed by adding present-tense endings onto the '''present tense stem''', which itself is sometimes hidden due to [[sound change]]s that have occurred in the past (more common verbs are listed): *bosti (bod-), vesti (ved- or vez-), krasti (krad-), iti (id-) *plesti (plet-), mesti (met-), greti (greb-), krasti (krad-) *rešti (rek-), pešti (pek-), mošti (mog-), tešti (tek-) There are several classes of verbs: 1. e-type verbs add the interfix ''-e-'' to the present stem (except in front of ''-ǫ'') and the endings: {| class="wikitable" |- ! Verb ! Singular ! Plural ! Dual |- | bosti (bod-) ("be (future)") | {{unbulleted list |1. bod -'''ǫ''' |2. bod -'''e''' + -'''ši''' |3. bod -'''e''' + -'''tъ''' }} | {{unbulleted list |1. bod -'''e''' + -'''mъ''' |2. bod -'''e''' + -'''te''' |3. bod -'''ǫtъ''' }} | {{unbulleted list |1. bod -'''e''' + -'''vě''' |2. bod -'''e''' + -'''ta''' |3. bod -'''e''' + -'''te''' }} |- | rešti (rek-) ("speak") | {{unbulleted list |1. rek -'''ǫ''' |2. reč -'''e''' + -'''ši''' |3. reč -'''e''' + -'''tъ''' }} | {{unbulleted list |1. reč -'''e''' + -'''mъ''' |2. reč -'''e''' + -'''te''' |3. rek -'''ǫtъ''' }} | {{unbulleted list |1. reč -'''e''' + -'''vě''' |2. reč -'''e''' + -'''ta''' |3. reč -'''e''' + -'''te''' }} |} 2. i-type verbs exhibit the same set of endings, but this time the interfix is ''-i-'' (except in front of ''-ǫ'' and ''-ę''). In the first person singular one finds the processes of [[iotation]] (''k/c + j > č, g/z + j > ž, x/s + j > š, l + j > lj, n + j > nj, t + j > št, d + j > žd'') and [[epenthesis]] (''bj > blj, pj > plj, mj > mlj, vj > vlj''): {| class="wikitable" |- ! Verb ! Singular ! Plural ! Dual |- | xvaliti (xval-) ("praise") | {{unbulleted list |1. xval + -'''j''' + -'''ǫ''' |2. xval -'''i''' + -'''ši''' |3. xval -'''i''' + -'''tъ''' }} | {{unbulleted list |1. xval -'''i''' + -'''mъ''' |2. xval -'''i''' + -'''te''' |3. xval -'''ętъ''' }} | {{unbulleted list |1. xval -'''i''' + -'''vě''' |2. xval -'''i''' + -'''ta''' |3. xval -'''i''' + -'''te''' }} |- | ljubiti (ljub-) ("love") | {{unbulleted list |1. ljub + -'''lj''' + -'''ǫ''' |2. ljub -'''i''' + -'''ši''' |3. ljub -'''i''' + -'''tъ''' }} | {{unbulleted list |1. ljub -'''i''' + -'''mъ''' |2. ljub -'''i''' + -'''te''' |3. ljub -'''ętъ''' }} | {{unbulleted list |1. ljub -'''i''' + -'''vě''' |2. ljub -'''i''' + -'''ta''' |3. ljub -'''i''' + -'''te''' }} |} 3. The athematic verbs ''byti'', ''dati'', ''věděti'', ''iměti'' and ''jasti'' form the present tense irregularly: {| class="wikitable" |- ! Verb ! Singular ! Plural ! Dual |- | byti ("be") | {{unbulleted list |1. jesmь |2. jesi |3. jestъ }} | {{unbulleted list |1. jesmъ |2. jeste |3. sǫtъ }} | {{unbulleted list |1. jesvě |2. jesta |3. jeste }} |- | věděti ("know") | {{unbulleted list |1. věmь |2. věsi |3. věstъ }} | {{unbulleted list |1. věmъ |2. věste |3. vědętъ }} | {{unbulleted list |1. věvě |2. věsta |3. věste }} |- | iměti ("have") | {{unbulleted list |1. imamь |2. imaši |3. imatъ }} | {{unbulleted list |1. imamъ |2. imate |3. imǫtъ }} | {{unbulleted list |1. imavě |2. imata |3. imate }} |- | jasti ("eat") | {{unbulleted list |1. jamь |2. jasi |3. jastъ }} | {{unbulleted list |1. jamъ |2. jaste |3. jadętъ }} | {{unbulleted list |1. javě |2. jasta |3. jaste }} |} One should distinguish the verbs ''iměti'' (''imamь, imaši, imatъ''), ''imati'' (''jemljǫ, jemleši, jemletъ'') and ''jęti'' (''imǫ, imeši, imetъ''). Exceptional is also the verb ''xotěti'' which exhibits iotation even though it's not an i-type verb (''xoštǫ, xošteši, xoštetъ''). ===Asigmatic aorist=== The '''asigmatic aorist''' (also called '''root''' or '''simple''' aorist) was named after the loss of the phoneme /s/ in the inflection ([[Ancient Greek language|AGr.]] ''[[sigma]]''), i.e. there is no ''VsV > VxV'' change (intervocalic /s/ yielding /x/). Over time, the asigmatic aorist became increasingly marked as an archaic language feature and was eventually replaced by the other two [[aorist]] formations. The asigmatic aorist was formed by adding to the '''infinitive stem''' of e-type verbs with stem ending in a consonant (i.e. verbs with the infix ''-nǫ-'', which is dropped before the aorist endings, and verbs with the null infix) the following endings: '''''-ъ, -e, -e; -omъ, -ete, -ǫ; -ově, -eta, -ete'''''. {| class="wikitable" |- ! Verb ! Singular ! Plural ! Dual |- | pasti (pad-) ("fall") | 1. pad -'''ъ'''
2. pad -'''e'''
3. pad -'''e''' | 1. pad -'''omъ'''
2. pad -'''ete'''
3. pad -'''ǫ''' | 1. pad -'''ově'''
2. pad -'''eta'''
3. pad -'''ete''' |- | tešti (tek-) ("flow") | 1. tek -'''ъ'''
2. teč -'''e'''

2. teč -'''ete'''
3. tek -'''ǫ''' | 1. tek -'''ově'''
2. teč -'''eta'''

2. mož -'''e'''

2. mož -'''ete'''
